docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Running Past Reason'' (Op-Ed, Nov. 4), Dr. Jerome Groopman equates the pain of running a marathon to the pain of childbirth, both of which test the individual's limits of pain and are followed by exhilaration and an unmatched sense of accomplishment. Why, then, is our society so willing to diminish the experience of childbirth for women through epidural anesthesia, while they cheer the men (and women) who brave the pain of the marathon, running toward the finish line, filled with pride?

docs.lead_paragraph: LeRoy Carhart seems to be an unlikely lightning rod. A 59-year-old doctor in small-city Nebraska and a 21-year veteran of the Air Force, Dr. Carhart attends a Methodist church, is an active member of the Republican Party and has been married for 36 years to a woman he met in the fifth grade.

headline.main: After Abortion Victory, Doctor's Troubles Persist

docs.abstract: Abortion foes make life difficult for Bellevue, Neb, surgeon Dr LeRoy Carhart, who successfully challenged constitutionality of state's abortion law banning partial-birth abortions in US Supreme Court; he faces eviction from his local clinic, has been removed from unpaid faculty position at University Nebraska College of Medicine, and anti-abortion group has sent letters to 13 mayors in area asking them to declare publicly their opposition to Carhart's moving practice to their towns; remains hero to abortion-rights movement, and says he is determined to stand his ground; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE Hollywood executives were professing before a Senate committee not long ago to be shocked, shocked, that somehow R-rated slasher movies like ''I Know What You Did Last Summer'' were being test-marketed to 9-year-olds, the news arrived from London that Tracy Emin, the popular British artist, had unveiled ''I've Got It All.'' Ms. Emin has made herself internationally known in art circles in recent years in shows like ''Sensation'' and, most famously, with pithy confessional installations entailing soiled underpants, cigarette butts, empty vodka bottles and used condoms. Her latest work, at London's Saatchi Gallery, includes a big photograph of herself splay-legged, giving birth to a wad of cash -- the currencies, you might note, hailing from the countries where she has had exhibitions.

docs.lead_paragraph: SO much for the end of the year as the season of serious films for grown-ups. As the holidays approach, escapism is running rampant. Moviegoers can find Terence Stamp rocketing to Mars, Christine Baranski hanging out in Whoville and Jeremy Irons battling evil in a fantasy empire. Actual distant lands are popular, too, with an unusual number of films from Asia. And most of the children's films are set on other continents. Even close to home, the world seems to be awash in vampires, werewolves, seemingly normal humans with supernatural powers and young people close to the Devil. At least most of the documentaries are serious. And in the midst of it all, there are love stories, war dramas and portraits of artists as violently talented men. Opening dates, as always, are subject to change. November ''SUZHOU RIVER'' From mainland China, a modernist film noir about a videomaker's attraction to two women (played ''Vertigo'' style by the same actress). One is an exotic dancer; the other is a teenager in love with a motorcycle messenger. Lou Ye is the director. Zhou Xun and Jia Hongsheng star. Opens Wednesday. ''ANGEL'S LADIES'' A documentary about Angel and Mack Moore, an Oregon couple who retired to Nevada to run a legal brothel. And are darned proud of it. Directed by Doug Lindeman, who has produced films about the pornographic film industry and lesbian bars. Friday. ''LOOKING FOR AN ECHO'' Where are the doo-wop stars of yesteryear? Armand Assante plays one, now 50, widowed and tending bar in Brooklyn. Then he meets a woman (Diane Venora) and all sorts of feelings, including his love for music, spring back to life. Directed by Martin Davidson (''The Lords of Flatbush''). Friday. ''ME AND ISAAC NEWTON'' The newest documentary from Michael Apted, who did the acclaimed ''Seven-Up'' series of films. Noted scientists talk about their specialties including robots, lemurs and a unified theory of everything. Friday. ''MEN OF HONOR'' The first black Navy SEAL and the racist senior officer who hates him, at first. Cuba Gooding Jr. and Robert De Niro star. Directed by George Tillman Jr., who wrote and directed ''Soul Food.'' Friday. ''NONSTOP'' A comic chase movie featuring a bank robber, a convenience store clerk and a mobster racing through the streets of Tokyo. Written and directed by Sabu (a k a Hiroyuki Tanaka). Friday. ''REBELS WITH A CAUSE'' Remembering S.D.S., the college organization that put the radical politics in the 60's. A documentary by Helen Garvy, who helped found Students for a Democratic Society's Harvard chapter in 1962. Friday. ''RED PLANET'' Val Kilmer does sci-fi. He plays a member of the American astronaut team on the first manned flight to Mars. Everyone's a little stressed, because Earth is on its last legs and a Martian colony is their only hope, so there are a few emotional flare-ups. With Benjamin Bratt, Terence Stamp and Carrie-Anne Moss. Directed by Anthony Hoffman. Friday. ''YOU CAN COUNT ON ME'' She's a respectable churchgoing single mom. He's an irresponsible drifter. They're sister and brother, reunited in their childhood home and having unexpected effects on each other. Their story, starring Laura Linney and Mark Ruffalo, won two major prizes at this year's Sundance Film Festival. Written and directed by the playwright Kenneth Lonergan. Friday. ''BOUNCE'' Gwyneth Paltrow and Ben Affleck together again. He's a hip L.A. ad man who gives away his airline seat on a flight that crashes, then falls in love with the widow of the man who took his place. Shades of Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas's ''Random Hearts.'' This one is written and directed by Don Roos, who did the terrific ''Opposite of Sex.'' Nov. 17. ''DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS'' If you're going to bring the grouchy green Grinch to life, Jim Carrey is probably your best bet, even if he's unrecognizable in fur. The Grinch, as every child knows, is determined to keep the residents of Whoville from celebrating their favorite holiday. Ron Howard directed. Christine Baranski, Molly Shannon and Bill Irwin play Whos. Nov. 17. A related article is on Page 9. ''LA BUCHE'' Three sisters in Paris deal with multiple romantic problems during Christmas week (unplanned pregnancy, straying husband, married lover, handsome young handyman with a secret). Emmanuelle Beart, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Sabine Azema star. Directed by Daniele Thompson. Nov. 17. Related articles are on Page 3. ''LIES'' Sadomasochism in South Korea. A teenage virgin and a much older sculptor meet, get kinky and turn into sex addicts. Jang Sun Woo is the director. Nov. 17. ''LITTLE NICKY'' Adam Sandler as the Devil's son, who's forced to move from hell to New York and finds the transition tough. His job: find his two no-good brothers and restore the balance of good and evil in the world. Harvey Keitel plays Satan. Directed by Steve Brill, who wrote the ''Mighty Ducks'' movies. Nov. 17. ''ONE DAY IN SEPTEMBER'' Last year's Oscar winner for documentary feature, shown on HBO earlier this year, goes back to theaters. It's the story of the terrorist murders of Olympic athletes at the 1972 Summer Games in Munich. Directed by Kevin Macdonald. Nov. 17. ''RUGRATS IN PARIS -- THE MOVIE'' The little Pickleses and Finsters go abroad, presumably with their parents. The second movie based on the Nickelodeon series ''Rugrats,'' and the first was a joy. Nov. 17. ''SASAYAKI (MOONLIGHT WHISPERS)'' A high school romance about sexual degradation. The filmmakers compare it to an ''After School Special'' directed by Luis Bunuel. Actually directed (and written) by Akihiko Shiota. Nov. 17. ''THE SIXTH DAY'' Arnold Schwarzenegger in a futuristic thriller. He's been cloned and his wife (Wendy Crewson) can't tell the difference. He also makes an enemy of a ruthless gazillionaire (Tony Goldwyn) and his scientist partner (Robert Duvall). Directed by Roger Spottiswoode. Nov. 17. ''WHAT'S COOKING?'' Thanksgiving in Los Angeles with four families (black, Latino, Jewish and Vietnamese). The ensemble cast includes Alfre Woodard, Joan Chen, Mercedes Ruehl and Dennis Haysbert. Directed by Gurinder Chadha. Nov. 17. ''THE WOLVES OF KROMER'' A British mystery about gay werewolves. Two handsome young wolves (James Layton and Lee Williams) are framed for murder, and the whole village (including the local priest, who's a little wolfish himself) turns against them. It's a mix of love story, black comedy and folk tale. Will Gould, 22, is the director. Boy George, 39, narrates. Nov. 17. ''MALENA'' Think ''Summer of '42'' in Sicily with laughs. Giuseppe Tornatore, who made ''Cinema Paradiso,'' is the director. Monica Bellucci, who played Gene Hackman's wife in ''Under Suspicion,'' is the World War II widow adored by a group of Sicilian boys busy coming of age. Nov. 22. ''102 DALMATIANS'' Cruella De Vil goes to Paris. Glenn Close, back as Cruella in this live-action Disney sequel, is joined by Gerard Depardieu (as a dastardly French furrier) and scores of cute spotted dogs. Maybe they'll run into the Rugrats. Directed by Kevin Lima. Nov. 22. A related article is on Page 9. ''QUILLS'' The Marquis de Sade's twilight years. Geoffrey Rush plays the world's most sexually notorious noble, writing away in Charenton Asylum. Kate Winslet is the laundry worker who smuggles his erotica out. Michael Caine is the doctor who wants to cure him of this nasty habit. Directed by Philip Kaufman, who did ''The Right Stuff'' and ''Henry and June.'' Nov. 22. A related article is on Page 3. ''THE TRENCH'' The bloody Battle of the Somme, 1916. Directed by the novelist William Boyd. With Paul Nicholls and Daniel Craig. Nov. 22. ''TWO NINAS'' Amanda Peet, Cara Buono and Ron Livingston in a love story about two gorgeous women in love with the same man. Written and directed by Neil Turitz. Nov. 22. ''UNBREAKABLE'' It's the ''Sixth Sense'' team again (minus Haley Joel Osment). M. Night Shyamalan directs Bruce Willis as a man who miraculously survives a terrible train crash. (One has to ask immediately: Or does he?) Samuel L. Jackson plays a man with an explanation for it. Nov. 22. ''THE WEEKEND'' Gena Rowlands, Jared Harris, Deborah Kara Unger, Brooke Shields and others at a country house to commemorate the anniversary of the death of a man they all cared about. Brian Skeet wrote and directed. Nov. 22. December ''A GOOD BABY'' One critic called it ''Flannery O'Connor meets Krzysztof Kieslowski.'' Henry Thomas plays a reclusive young North Carolina man who finds an abandoned baby in the woods and goes searching for its mother. Directed by Katherine Dieckmann, making her feature film debut. Dec. 1. ''SPRING FORWARD'' A year in the workday partnership of a young ex-con (Liev Schreiber) and an imminent parks department retiree (Ned Beatty). It's a sensitive guy thing, written and directed by Tom Gilroy. Dec. 1. ''TERROR FIRMER'' From Troma Entertainment, which regularly sinks to new levels of weird bad taste (see ''Tromeo and Juliet,'' for starters), the story of a film crew, a blind director (played by the film's director, Lloyd Kaufman) and a sexually confused serial killer. Dec. 1. ''FINDING FORRESTER'' A male mentor picture from Gus Van Sant. Sean Connery is a reclusive novelist; Rob Brown, a newcomer, is a young basketball star who, it turns out, is also a brilliant writer. Is that the theme music to ''Good Will Hunting'' we hear? With Busta Rhymes, F. Murray Abraham, Anna Paquin and, as a Yankee stadium guard, Joey Buttafuoco. Dec. 6. ''HILLBROW KIDS'' Street children in South Africa, begging, getting high and trying to stay alive. Jacqueline Gorgen and Michael Hammon directed this documentary, named for a tough Johannesburg neighborhood. Dec. 6. ''THE ART OF AMALIA'' A documentary tribute to the hugely popular Portuguese fado singer Amalia Rodrigues, who died last year. This is Bruno de Almeida's fourth film about her. Dec. 8. ''BOYS LIFE 3'' Five short films about gay life, including ''Majorettes in Space.'' There's star power this time: Sara Gilbert as star and director of ''$30'' and Jason Gould as star and director of ''Inside Out,'' which also features his father, Elliot Gould, and Christina Crawford. Dec. 8. ''CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON'' After ''The Ice Storm'' and ''Sense and Sensibility,'' Ang Lee looks homeward. Chow Yun Fat and Michelle Yeoh star in this martial arts film set in ancient China. A love story too, it was a huge hit at the Cannes International Film Festival. Dec. 8. A related article is on Page 25. ''THE DAY SILENCE DIED'' Magic realism in Bolivia. A small, isolated town gets its first radio and everybody overreacts. Directed by Paolo Agazzi. Dec. 8. ''DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS'' Jeremy Irons and Thora Birch in a fantasy adventure about a young empress, an evil magician, magic rods and scepters, deadly mazes and secret grottoes. It's based on one generation's favorite game and goes heavy on the visual effects. Courtney Solomon is the first-time director. Dec. 8. ''PROOF OF LIFE'' Russell Crowe and Meg Ryan star as a hostage negotiator and a hostage's wife who fall in love. (Yes, this is where the stars' own romance began.) David Morse plays Ms. Ryan's husband. The film, set in South America, is directed by Taylor Hackford. Dec. 8. ''VERTICAL LIMIT'' Chris O'Donnell in an action-adventure story about a traumatized ex-mountaineer who may have to take up climbing again to save his sister (Robin Tunney), who is trapped 26,000 feet up. Originally scheduled for release last summer. Directed by Martin Campbell. Dec. 8. ''CHOCOLAT'' From Lasse Hallstrom, whose work includes ''My Life as a Dog'' to ''The Cider House Rules.'' Juliette Binoche plays a single mother who moves to a prudish French village and scandalizes everyone by opening a chocolaterie with sinfully good merchandise. Johnny Depp plays another outsider, Alfred Molina the head prude. Dec. 15. ''DUDE, WHERE'S MY CAR?'' Party-loving young men forget where they parked. A comedy about losing your girlfriend's anniversary present. With Ashton Kutcher of ''That 70's Show.'' Directed by Danny Leiner. Dec. 15. ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW GROOVE'' Disney's animated extravaganza of the season, a buddy movie set in South America. It seems a selfish young emperor is turned into a llama by a disgruntled ex-employee. But when he teams up with a humble llama herder, he becomes a much nicer human being. With the voices of David Spade, Eartha Kitt and John Goodman. Directed by Mark Dindal. Music by Sting. Dec. 15. ''FAMILY MAN'' A romantic comedy for Christmas. Imagine George Bailey in ''It's a Wonderful Life'' as a fast-lane bachelor investment banker. That's Jack Campbell (Nicolas Cage), who wakes up one December morning to find himself married with children and a minivan. Tea Leoni is his wife in this alternative existence. Brett Ratner, who did ''Rush Hour,'' directed. Dec. 15. A related article is on Page 3. ''POLLOCK'' Ed Harris directs himself as Jackson Pollock, Abstract Expressionist genius, midcentury American celebrity and self-hating alcoholic. Marcia Gay Harden plays the artist Lee Krasner, his wife. Val Kilmer turns up as Willem de Kooning. This biography was the New York Film Festival's official centerpiece, and highly praised. December 15. ''WHAT WOMEN WANT'' Mel Gibson as an ad executive who suddenly develops the ability to read women's minds. He promptly takes advantage. With Helen Hunt, Marisa Tomei and Lauren Holly. Nancy Meyers, who did ''The Parent Trap'' (and was a co-writer on ''Private Benjamin'' and ''Baby Boom''), directed. Dec. 15. ''BUT FOREVER IN MY MIND'' An Italian comedy about teenage hormones, male bonding and the shadow of the 1960's student protests. Silvio Muccino stars, Gabriele Muccino directed, and the two wrote the script together. Dec. 20. ''THIRTEEN DAYS'' Kevin Costner plays a presidential aide in a behind-the-scenes drama about the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Bruce Greenwood plays J. F. K. Roger Donaldson directed. Dec. 20. A related article is on Page 19. ''BEFORE NIGHT FALLS''' The artist Julian Schnabel tries film directing again (he did ''Basquiat''), this time with a biography of Reinaldo Arenas, the exiled Cuban poet and novelist. Javier Bardem plays Arenas, who committed suicide (he had AIDS) in 1990. Johnny Depp also stars. The film was very well received at the New York Film Festival this year. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 44. ''CAST AWAY'' Tom Hanks in Robinson Crusoe mode (and weight). He's a stressed-out FedEx worker now trying to survive alone on a desert island after his plane crashes. Helen Hunt is the woman he left behind. Directed by Robert Zemeckis, whose last film with Mr. Hanks (''Forrest Gump'') turned out pretty well. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 1. ''THE GIFT'' Cate Blanchett, Hilary Swank, Keanu Reeves and Greg Kinnear in a Southern Gothic thriller written by Billy Bob Thornton and Tim Epperson. Ms. Blanchett is a small-town Georgia widow with psychic powers. But like all movie towns, this one has secrets and she sees a little too much. Sam Raimi directed. Dec. 22. ''THE HOUSE OF MIRTH'' Edith Wharton's 1905 New York, rich with cruelty, hypocrisy and greed -- and one woman's descent from its upper class. Gillian Anderson stars as Lily Bart, with Eric Stoltz, Dan Aykroyd, Anthony La Paglia and Terry Kinney as the men of varying intentions around her. Terence Davies wrote and directed. Dec. 22. ''MISS CONGENIALITY'' Sandra Bullock plays an F.B.I. agent posing as a Miss New Jersey contestant in order to prevent a bombing. It's a comedy. Benjamin Bratt, Michael Caine and William Shatner are her co-stars. Directed by Donald Petrie, who did ''Grumpy Old Men.'' Dec. 22. ''NOWHERE TO HIDE'' A Korean detective looking for a murderer. Directed by Lee Myung-Se. Dec. 22. ''O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU?'' Loved him in the E.R. Loved him tossed at sea. Now will we love George Clooney on the road in rural Mississippi? He plays an escaped convict in Joel and Ethan Coen's tribute to Preston Sturges's 1941 film ''Sullivan's Travels,'' a sort of Depression-era ''Odyssey.'' They liked it a lot at the Cannes International Film Festival. With John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 29. ''STATE AND MAIN'' David Mamet makes fun of movie people. Alec Baldwin, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy and Sarah Jessica Parker star as part of a film cast and crew who invade a quiet Vermont town, armed with cell phones and portable egos. Julia Stiles plays a local teenager who gets close to one of them. Dec. 22. ''WES CRAVEN PRESENTS: DRACULA 2000'' What if Count Dracula were around today, surrounded by all those young Goths in America? He is. Gerard Butler and Jonny Lee Miller star, and Christopher Plummer plays Van Helsing. Mr. Craven is an executive producer; Patrick Lussier, who worked with him on ''Scream 2'' and ''Scream 3,'' directed. Dec. 22. ''ALL THE PRETTY HORSES'' Matt Damon and Henry Thomas as Texas teenagers who head for Mexico to be cowboys. We've been waiting more than a year now for this one, based on Cormac McCarthy's award-winning western novel, set in the 1940's. With Penlope Cruz. Billy Bob Thornton directed. Dec. 25. ''AN EVERLASTING PIECE'' Barry Levinson gets out of Baltimore -- to do a comedy about barbers in Belfast. It's the story of a Protestant and a Roman Catholic who become highly unlikely partners in a toupee business in Northern Ireland. Barry McEvoy and Brian F. O'Byrne are the stars. Dec. 25. ''VATEL'' A 17th-century costume drama with a Tom Stoppard script (written with Jeanne LaBrune). Gerard Depardieu stars as Louis XIV's caterer, in love with the king's favorite courtesan (Uma Thurman). Roland Joffe directed. Dec. 25. ''TRAFFIC'' The latest from Steven Soderbergh (''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' ''Erin Brockovich''), a thriller about the drug trade. Michael Douglas stars as anti-drug czar designate; Catherine Zeta-Jones is a drug lord's wife who runs the business. Don Cheadle plays a narc. Dec. 27. ''CHUNHYANG'' An operatic love story set in 18th-century Korea. The governor's son and the courtesan's daughter love each other, and that means trouble. Directed by Im Kwon Taek, who interweaves pansori, a stylized musical-narrative . Cho Seung Woo and Lee Hyo Jung star. Dec. 29. A related article is on Page 25. ''THE CLAIM'' Thomas Hardy's novel ''The Mayor of Casterbridge'' with the names and location changed. But it's still about a poor man who sells his wife and his daughter for a not-so-proverbial pot of gold, then suffers when they come back to haunt him 20 years later. He just happens to be rich and successful now. Peter Mullan, Nastassja Kinski, Milla Jovovich, Sarah Polley and Wes Bentley star. Michael Winterbottom (''Wonderland'') directed. Dec. 29. ''SHADOW OF THE VAMPIRE'' The year is 1922, and the pioneering German director F. W. Murnau (John Malkovich) is making his silent horror classic ''Nosferatu.'' Willem Dafoe plays the film's star, Max Schreck, who appears to be a real vampire. This is not good news for cast and crew. E. Elias Merhige, a first-timer, directed. Dec. 29. A related article is on Page 3. ''SIMON MAGUS'' Noah Taylor (he was the young David Helfgott in ''Shine'') plays a 19th-century boy whose fellow villagers believe he's possessed by the Devil. It's a horror fantasy romance that revolves around plans for a railway station, directed by Ben Hopkins, a first-timer. With Ian Holm as the Devil. Dec. 29. ''THE VISIT'' A prison drama starring Hill Harper (Dr. Wesley Williams on CBS's ''City of Angels''). Mr. Harper plays a terminally ill young man whose family rarely turns up on visitors' day. Billy Dee Williams and Marla Gibbs portray his parents and Obba Babatunde his successful-businessman brother. Jordan Walker-Pearlman wrote and directed. December. January ''NIGHT WALTZ: THE MUSIC OF PAUL BOWLES'' Owsley Brown's documentary about Bowles, the expatriate author who died a year ago this month, and his lesser-known career as a composer. Jan. 3. ''THE PERSONALS'' From China, a comedy about a young woman who places an ad to find a husband. Directed by Chen Kuo-Fu. Jan. 5. ''TERRORISTS IN RETIREMENT'' Simone Signoret narrated this 1984 documentary a year before she died. It's the story of Jewish immigrants in Nazi-occupied Paris, taking the most dangerous assignments in the Resistance. The surviving fighters, elderly men now, are interviewed, and what they say doesn't always reflect well on the official Resistance. Maybe that's why it was originally banned from French television. Directed by Mosco Boucault. Jan. 10. ''ANTITRUST'' Dark doings in the computer industry. Ryan Phillippe plays the eager young software designer. Tim Robbins, the company's billionaire founder, is his mentor. Peter Howitt (''Sliding Doors'') directed. Jan. 12. ''THE PLEDGE'' That old story about a cop nanoseconds away from retirement who becomes involved in something big, in this case an 8-year-old girl's murder. But it could be nice to see Jack Nicholson in ''Chinatown'' mode again. And he has an amazing supporting cast, including Vanessa Redgrave, Sam Shepard and Helen Mirren. The uncompromising Sean Penn directed. Jan. 12. ''SAVE THE LAST DANCE'' Hip-hop versus ballet in a musical drama directed by Thomas Carter. With Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas. Jan. 12. Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor.

docs.lead_paragraph: CHRISTMAS EVE was always a production at our house. The towering tree in the central hall, covered with shiny red ornaments, draped in silvery tinsel, lighted with real candles. The staff, in their long black uniforms with starched white aprons and caps, setting out piles of gorgeously wrapped gifts underneath the tree. There were tall white candles on the dining table, where after dinner (which always began at 4:30 p.m.) we sang and toasted everyone's health. Mother wore red brocade and Father, like all the men in the family, wore white tie. Eventually we all held hands and danced through the house, singing until we fell, exhausted, into our chairs and listened to an uncle read the Nativity story from the second chapter of Luke. In lovely, lilting Swedish. Oh, no, wait, that was ''Fanny and Alexander.''

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S 4:30 on a Saturday afternoon, and while others were preparing for a night on the town, Luz Bovell, munching on Cheez Doodles and coordinating a network of outreach workers over her cell phone, was preparing for work. In the web of social services that the county provides for its neediest citizens, street outreach is among the most easily overlooked. But Ms. Bovell, outreach director for the Children's Village residential treatment center in Dobbs Ferry, is changing that.

docs.lead_paragraph: The statistic has not yet lost its power to shock: about a third of the births in this country each year are to unmarried mothers. By almost any measure, the rise in the proportion of babies born outside marriage, from less than 1 in 20 in 1960 to 1 in 3 now, has been among the most profound changes in American society.

headline.main: Is Social Stability Subverted If You Answer 'I Don't'?; Fears for Children's Well-Being Complicate a Debate Over Marriage

docs.abstract: Article discusses rise in proportion of babies born outside marriage from less than 1 in 20 in 1960 to 1 in 3 now; United States and other rich countries are moving toward 'post marriage society,' stemming from ambivalence of feminists, and young people whose parents' divorces have made them cynical about its permanence; Martha Fineman, professor at Cornell Law School, contends obsession with marriage prevents us from looking at and addressing our social problems; scholars agree that it is important to protect well-being of children, but disagree whether best approach is to encourage marriage or adjust to new social mores by finding better ways to support unmarried parents; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Jay Dickey, a four-term Republican congressman in an overwhelmingly Democratic district, is not an elegant speaker. But as he spoke from atop a flatbed trailer at this town's annual timber festival this weekend, he was a model of oratorical efficiency. Despite his halting style, in less than two minutes he neatly summarized his unyielding conservative positions and emphasized the value of his seat on the Appropriations Committee, which he has used with stunning success to bring rewards to the district, most notably millions of dollars in federal highway construction funds.
